page.title: 11THE RIVER DON
page.content: THE SHEFFIELD AND SOUTH YORKSHIRE NAVIGATION USES THE RIVER DON AS ITS MAIN ARTERY,SUPPLEMENTED BY A SYSTEM OF CANALS.THE DON NAVIGATION ACT OF THE EIGHTEENTH CENTURY INCREASED PLANS FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF WATER TRANSPORT IN SOUTH YORKSHIRE.DONCASTER IS AN INLAND TOWN AND THE SOUTH YORKSHIRE NAVIGATION LINKED SHEFFIELD TO THE RIVER TRENT AT KEADBY IN 1821,AND THUS DIRECTLY TO THE HUMBER ESTUARY AND THE NORTH SEA.COAL AND MINERAL ORES ARE THE CHIEF CARGOES.NOWADAYS THE COAL IS TAKEN FROM THE COLLIERIES IN LARGE PANS,LOCALLY KNOWN AS 'TOM PUDDINGS', PULLED BY DIESEL ENGINED BARGES. CANALS ARE NOW CONTROLLED BY THE BRITISH TRANSPORT COMMISSION,AND MODERNISATION PLANS INCLUDE THE FACILITY FOR LARGER CONTAINER BARGES WHICH WILL HANDLE INCREASED TONNAGE.
